instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PM_S0_PGOOD: What is PM_S0_PGOOD?  PM_S0_PGOOD is created when CPUVR_PGOOD and ALL_SYS_PWRGD are present and branches off to become PM_PCH_PWROK. PM_S0_PGOOD and SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD are necessary to create SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message:
ï¿¼Liquid-damaged. Light corrosion in a few places (see pics) including the area around the SPI ROM chip. <SIGNAL>SPI_SMC_CS_L</SIGNAL> is measuring 1.38V instead of 3.3V. <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> is measuring 3.3V.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is at around 0.3V, then it slowly drops, and then jumps up to 3.3 for split-second. <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_X1</SIGNAL> is at 0.8V and <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_X2</SIGNAL> is at 0.06V. Because I don't know if you should have a clock at this point I replaced <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and Y1905. Not sure where to go next.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: I can't see anything on those pictures. Was there corrosion around <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message:
No Title

Ok, I'll have to make a request to Louis to change the image upload converter settings for the forum. The pics are high-res but are getting dumbed down. There is corrosion around <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>. I cropped the pics and uploaded them. Hopefully they're somewhat useable.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: First clean it off and check all the traces and resistors that are in serie with the data lines.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: Ok, I don't like to work on them until I clean them in the ultrasonic so any previous notes were after cleaning. I checked all of the lines in that entire area and they're all good. I checked all of the resistor values too and they're fine.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: Any other thoughts on this? These 2015 Airs are killing me right now.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: How does <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> look?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: Looks good. Diode measurements match a good board. I attached pics of the other 3 spots that got hit.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: No Title

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: If that is <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> in the first picture then it's pretty crusty. I bet the power pin has corroded away under it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: Yes, you're right, that is <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and it definitely looks like it got hit. I replaced it with a known-good chip. No change.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: Was the power pin still good on the board? Many times it is corroded and will not provide good contact.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: Yeah, everything looks good. It looks like it wasn't hit. I'm measuring 3.42V on the pin. When I measure on Pin 5 (<SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL>) I'm seeing a short pulse up to 3.4V  every 5 seconds or so.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: Is CPU Vcore pulsing too?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: Yes, it's also going up. It looks like it's hitting a normal voltage when it pulses, maybe slightly high. Somewhere around 1V, slightly higher or lower at times.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: That means all power is ok. Pulse on <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR> also present? What is voltage on Y1905 pulsing at?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message:
Yes, it seems to be hitting about 0.6V on <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR>.
It looks like it's hitting the correct voltage on Y1905 when it pulses. <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_X2</SIGNAL> is hitting around 0.9V and <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_X1</SIGNAL> is hitting around 1.3V (it stays at around 0.8V when not pulsing.)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR> should spike at 3V, preferably use a scope, multimeter is too slow.
What is the voltage on Y1905?? Should not spike over 1.6V on both pins.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message:
Yes, <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR> is hitting around 3V.

Y1905:
Pin 1: <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_X2</SIGNAL> is hitting around 0.9V
Pin2: <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_X1</SIGNAL> is hitting around 1.3V (it stays at around 0.8V when not pulsing.)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: Well, I'm out of ideas then. You can pull ROM chip and measure all pins on diode mode.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: Ok, I'll try that. Is the order of things: power --> pgood --> clock --> ROM? I know that's way oversimplified but I'm trying to figure out where the stopping point might be. If <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR> was lower would that have meant no pgood?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: So does this mean that the ROM chip (or it's circuit) could be responsible for this? It's not something that happens before the ROM chip is accessed? I have no idea of the order of events when it turns on so I'm not sure of the logic.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: If the system cannot access the ROM it will power cycle like it is doing now.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: Ok, good to know, I thought the fan would cycle on and off even without the ROM functioning.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: Actually the fan would be cycling, but the pulse is so short the fan has no time to start up. Without the ROM all S3 and S0 busses will be pulsing.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message:
No Title

Ok, so pin 1 on the SPI ROM is open - no reading in diode mode. ROM is removed. Pin 1 has continuity to <CHIP>U6101</CHIP>. I've replaced <CHIP>U6101</CHIP>. I'm not exactly sure of the orientation of the <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> chips I just got in the mail. I'm attaching a picture. I'm assuming the bottom right is pin 1. No dot, just a line. Any thoughts?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: Get a scrap board so you can also compare measurements and take the correct chip from the donor. I'm pretty sure pin 1 should have something on diode mode with red to GND. All pins must measure something at least. I have no scrap 00165 to compare here right now to be 100% sure. Just order a pile of scrap boards, you will need them anyway.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message:
Yeah, I compared it to a another 00165 and it's supposed to be around .590 with <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> present and ROM removed. It's open with <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> and ROM removed. I've used up all of my <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> chips from donor boards. That chip is only on 2015 Air and Retina boards so they went fast which is why I bought a large quantity of new ones. Just wasn't sure of the orientation but I have it now (opposite of my pic.)

âSo, the results: No change after installing newly purchased <CHIP>U6101</CHIP>. And no change after installing known-good ROM and factory <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> from other 00165 board. It still gets 0V on pin1 of ROM and around 1.1V on <SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_CS_L</SIGNAL> / <SIGNAL>SPI_SMC_CS_L</SIGNAL>. Also, I've confirmed that <SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_CS_L</SIGNAL> / <SIGNAL>SPI_SMC_CS_L</SIGNAL> will measure 3.3V on a good board with no ROM or <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> installed.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message:
If there is no diode mode measurement on pin 1 then <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> is not soldered right. Check all pins of <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> on diode mode with it removed and ROM installed of course. Must be bad trace somewhere.
Also do not swap ROMs between boards you will have ME issues, put back original!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message:
Sorry, I left that out of the results above. The measurements on this ROM are normal now (.590 on pin 1) with the known-good <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> installed correctly. I had the open result because I had <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> reversed.  As far as the ROM swap, it's only for testing. No intention of leaving them that way. To be sure of things, I tested this boards ROM and <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> on my known-good board and it powers up normally.

So the problem is with <SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_CS_L</SIGNAL> / <SIGNAL>SPI_SMC_CS_L</SIGNAL> not hitting 3.3V. It's at around 1.1V. It looks <SIGNAL>SPI_SMC_CS_L</SIGNAL> comes from the SMC. Diode measurements on that line are at .615 versus .515 on a good board.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: Remove <RESISTOR>R6117</RESISTOR> and check both sides on diode mode.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R6117</RESISTOR> Diode Measurements

This Board:
Pin 1: .733 - <SIGNAL>SPI_SMC_CS_L</SIGNAL>
Pin 2: .614 - <SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_CS_L</SIGNAL>

Good Board:
Pin 1: .730 - <SIGNAL>SPI_SMC_CS_L</SIGNAL>
Pin 2: .514 - <SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_CS_L</SIGNAL>

So this seems hopeful.
To take this a step farther I removed <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> on both boards.

Good board Pin 1 stays at .514.
Bad board goes open.

I tested the continuity between <RESISTOR>R6117</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R6120</RESISTOR> and <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> and it's good. Continuity through <RESISTOR>R6120</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R6125</RESISTOR> is good also. Both are measuring 43 ohms. Continuity to <RESISTOR>R6110</RESISTOR> is shot. I think I have the problem.

**I accidentally just hit Submit so this post is a little premature, but I'm about to run a wire. I'll update after the results.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: Got it, beautiful. This was a good win. 2015 i7 board. Thanks for getting me there.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No 3.3V on Pin1 of SPI-ROM
threads.message: No problem, but I already called it in post #4!
